{"id":360278564,"question_id":231,"lang":"python3","lang_name":"Python3","time":"4 years, 8 months","timestamp":1593530423,"status":10,"status_display":"Accepted","runtime":"40 ms","url":"/submissions/detail/360278564/","is_pending":"Not Pending","title":"Power of Two","memory":"14.1 MB","code":"import math\nclass Solution:\n    def isPowerOfTwo(self, n: int) -> bool:\n        if n == 1:\n            return True\n        n = n - 1\n        if n <= 0:\n            return False\n        t = math.ceil(log2(n))\n        for i in range(t):\n            if n & 1 << i == 0:\n                return False\n        return True \n'''\nThis is classical bit manipulation problem for n & (n-1) trick, which removes the last non-zero bit from our number\n\nexample:\n1.n = 100000, then n - 1 = 011111 and n & (n-1) = 000000, so if it is power of two, result is zero\n2.n = 101110, then n - 1 = 101101 and n & (n-1) = 101100, number is not power of two and result is not zero.\n\nclass Solution:\n    def isPowerOfTwo(self, n):\n        return n > 0 and not (n & n-1)\n'''","compare_result":"","title_slug":"power-of-two","has_notes":false,"flag_type":1}
